description: Erection of part single and part two storey side and rear extensions (following demolition of rear extensions and garage); replacement windows and erection of new boundary walls and gates to front
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

The facing materials used in the development to which this permission relates shall match those of the existing building(s) unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding condition 3 above, samples of any facing materials to be utilised which will not match those used in the existing building(s) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority prior to the commencement of any development above ground level. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, detailed drawings at a scale of 1:20 of the following features shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority:(i) windows, including any aprons, sills, mouldings, heads, jambs, transoms, mullions, lintels or revealsThe development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved drawings.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The rooflights in the development to which this permission relates shall be of a conservation style, constructed in timber and set flush with the plane of the roof in which they are inserted. The rooflights shall be permanently retained in this style. Reason: To prevent harm to the significance of designated heritage assets, in accordance with policy 7.8 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM12 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any rainwater goods used in the development to which this permission relates shall be cast iron or aluminium cast iron effect.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any windows or rooflights at first floor level or above in the south-eastern (flank) elevation shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any external lighting installed at the site shall be angled so as to prevent any spillage or glare beyond the site's boundaries.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with 'Arboricultural Impact Assessment and Method Statement' reference AC.2020.200 dated 28 May 2020 and drawing TPP-01 Rev A. The approved measures shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.
A1 - Loading

The submitted report Surface Water Drainage Design 5409 SWDD July 2022  by the applicant in relation to Condition 5  is considered to be sufficient. As such, this condition is hereby approved.An objection has been received, however, this does not raise any issues with the information submitted.

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted. The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks to amend Condition 16 so as to vary the trigger point for the submission of a Landscaping Scheme.Condition 16 was imposed on the Planning Permission for Demolition at a time when the Planning Application for the replacement Leisure Centre had not been approved. The replacement Leisure Centre (and associated works to the Library and landscaping) have now been approved.The proposed amendment, taken in light of the now approved replacement centre, would amount to a non-material amendment. The comments of the Kingston Town CAAC are noted (copied below). The comments of the CAAC appear to have been submitted on the basis that the condition is proposed to be removed, it is not - it is proposed to be amended with regards to trigger points. "This Condition should only be removed if a suitable interim landscape Condition is added that preserves the character and appearance of the Conservation Area. i.e.. care/maintenance of trees, grass, railings, etc is carried out and demolition site left in acceptable condition during the interim."

Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted. The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises an end of terrace dwelling house located on the corner of South Lane and Grayham Road. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Erection of single storey rear extension and alterations to the roof over the existing side extension.Consultations6 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed full width rear extension would project approximately 3m beyond the rear elevation and would be of a total height of approximately 3.3m, following Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD. The alteration to the existing roof over the side extension are noted and are considered acceptable in terms of the proposed scale, materials and design. The proposed extension would be fully visible within the street, however given its modest scale, the proposed design and materials it is considered that it would not have significant impact on the existing street scene. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.It is noted that the adjoining property No 62 South Lane benefits from the side extension. The proposed development would pass the 45 degree rule in relation to this property and therefore would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Statement which is considered sufficient. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted.The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks to amend the approved scheme by: Enlarging the proposed front and both sides dormers and new triangular loft window at rear elevationIn this case officers consider that an assessment would have to be made to ensure that the proposed changes would not give rise to any adverse impacts with regards to character and appearance and neighbouring residential amenity. As such, the proposed changes are not considered to be non-material.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; - Flood Risk Assessment; and, - Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the proposed hip-to-gable roof extension would not be in keeping with the requirements of the Residential Design SPD, as it would unbalance the roof forms of the pair of semi-detached properties, given that this aspect of the proposal could be completed under permitted development, officers consider that this would be a credible fallback position.The proposed rear dormer extension would not necessarily be appropriately set in from the sides or eaves of the roof slope, as per the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, however given that there would be an element of set in from the roof slope, and that it would be finished in materials to match the original dwelling, officers consider that it would not appear a dominant addition to the host property. As such, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. While the proposed rear extension would have a depth that is in excess of policy recommendations (5.7m v. 3.5m), given that the proposed extension would have a stepped depth, and a modest height, officers consider that it would not overwhelm the host property, further given that it would be situated in a fairly substantial plot, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the siting and modest scale of the proposed extensions on the boundary with the adjoining property, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of 49 Egmont Road by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Given that 53 Egmont Road is orientated further to the rear of the proposed extensions, and there would be a degree of separation between the flank wall of 53 Egmont Road and the proposed extensions, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of this neighbouring property by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Flood Risk AssessmentThe application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Officer Comment: The submitted flood risk assessment states that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate which is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Planning permission is sought for the demolition of existing conservatory and erection of single-storey rear extension.7 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals.  One representation has been received in support of the proposal subject to the external materials of the extension along the party wall remaining the same as the existing brickwork. A matter that is to be settled between the two parties outside of the planning process, although a condition would be imposed to ensure matching materials are used. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey would replace the existing conservatory extension to a depth of 5.5m from the rear wall of the host dwelling (2m beyond the existing conservatory extension). Whilst the extension would not accord with the parameters of the Residential Design SPD, in terms of depth, the proposed extension would utilise materials to match the host building, would not be of an inappropriate scale in relation to the host dwelling, and other examples of deeper rear extensions are evident in the immediate vicinity of the application property. Officers therefore consider the proposed extension would have an acceptable impact on the character or appearance of the area.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: The proposed extension would project beyond the neighbouring any further than the existing conservatory (to be demolished) however the conservatory to the neighbouring property at No. 35 Homersham Road is mostly glazed and as such the proposed extension is not considered to result in any additional adverse impact on this properties amenities in terms of daylight/sunlight or loss of outlook. No.31 Homersham Road is separated from the application property by a driveway to a neighbouring property. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, there is sufficient space for provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
Please provide an accurate description of works to the tree.
Please provide clear photos of each tree and any key features you wish to draw to the attention.

Please amend the red outline in the location plan to include Unit A and Unit B because the proposal is for alteration to the front part of Unit A and Unit B. Note: Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.

Please provide a Proposed Block Plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site. The Block Plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.
For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Alteration to front part of Unit A and Unit B, erection of 8.85m high entrance feature extension.'
